Award.AwardTitle: Regulation of Directionality of Cargo Transport by Molecular Motors
Award.AbstractNarration: In this project the PI will study the mechanisms by which opposite polarity motors communicate and how their function is regulated inside living cells. The standard genetic and biochemical assays will be combined with high speed imaging as well as quantitative optical trap measurement of motor forces in living Drosophila embryos and in purified systems from different genetic backgrounds. This research project is motivated by preliminary data showing that purified cargos carry opposite polarity motors that engage in a stalemate in vitro and do not move long distances in the absence of cyotsolic extracts. The central hypothesis is that regulatory proteins coordinate bidirectional transport and that force generation in opposite directions alone does not account for the observed bidirectionality. The rationale for these studies is that the identification of the mechanisms by which motors of opposite polarity cooperate would lead to a fundamental framework for eventual understanding of how failure of these mechanisms is linked to disease. The principal investigator has, and will continue to disseminate the findings of his research program among the general public through high school student internships in his laboratory and through lectures to the students and their teachers in Austin high schools.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Much like a city, living cells are organized, and maintaining their organization is essential for their proper functioning. To position micrometer-sized vesicles and organelles inside the cell at the right place and in a timely fashion the cell shuttles these cargoes along a network of intracellular roads (microtubules and actin filaments) using a set of cellular vehicles: molecular motor proteins (kinesin, dynein and myosin) (see figure 1). Of course, the roads and motors are tiny: you need to put a thousand microtubules in a bundle to get the thickness of one human hair. Moreover, the motors are often tiny compared to the cargo; think of a huge heap of hay carried by a poor donkey that is barely visible beneath it. The motor proteins use the energy released by ATP hydrolysis, the cellular ‘fuel’, to generate the force they need to haul the cargoes; thus, measuring that force amounts to directly probing their function.

 In this project, we developed methods that enabled us to measure how strong these motors are and probe their function in their native cellular environment. Measuring the piconewoton forces (one trillionth of the force you need to carry an apple!) that motors exert in their native cellular environment enabled us to count the number of motors hauling individual cargoes as two motors working in tandem exert twice the force of one motor (see figure 2). Now, the analogy with roads, vehicles, donkeys and fuel sort of drops here: on a road you can typically make a U-turn, in the cell if you want to reverse direction you need to switch ‘vehicles’. One type of molecular motor (kinesin) walks in one direction only while another (dynein) walks in the opposite direction. We found that cargoes carry teams of both of these motors simultaneously, which opens the obvious question of whether these motors engage in a tug-of-war. While this may sound like a futile effort if the cell wants to deliver cargo, one should remember that things are not always efficient inside the cell and that it often resorts to simple ways of achieving a certain goal. Indeed, mathematical models suggested that two teams of motors engaging in a tug-of-war can lead to back-and-forth motion of the cargo along the microtubule, which can be tuned to result in the cargo eventually reaching its destination. Being able to probe individual motor function directly inside the cell, allowed us to test whether these motors do indeed fight as this model suggested. We discovered that they don’t! Dynein is ‘stubborn’; it latches on more firmly to the microtubule when pulled by a stronger force, while kinesin gives under increased load. This suggests that they would be incompatible teams in a potential tug-of-war. Indeed, their function seems to be regulated by other means as our measurements indicate that when one motor type is active, the other is not.   

 Given the ubiquity of molecular motors, failure in regulating their function can result in failed cargo delivery inside the cell which could lead to disease. Neurodegenerative diseases such as Alzheimer’s, Huntington and Amyotrophic Lateral Sclerosis, for example, have been linked to motor malfunction within neurons. We used a fruit fly model of Alzheimer’s disease to study how motor malfunction is regulated. Cells that make up the fly are very similar to our own cells and most of the genetic diseases that we have originate in genes that are also found in the fly making it a great model to start to understand what goes wrong in these diseases.
